                    Text: 
                    Jan 18, 1887 Amphetamine was first synthesized at Universität Berlin by Romanian chemist Lazar Edeleanu 1861-1941  and originally named phenylisopropylamine.  It was then largely forgotten for the next 40 years. 1 [Details] During his doctorat with the celebrated professor A. W. Hofmann, he discovered the phenylizopropylamine, known today as "benzendrine" . He worked in Germany (1910 - 1932), as director of  "Allgemeine Gesellschaft für Chemiche Industrie", which, in honor of the Romanian inventor, was named  "Edeleanu Gesellschaft" and is still operating in Frankfurt. This  firm  registered in 1932 the "Edeleanu" patent, still in force which made major contributions to products involving carburetors, motor oils, etc. 1919 Methamphetamine is first synthesized by Japanese scientist A. Ogata. 1930 Amphetamine was discovered to increase blood pressure. 2 1932 Amphetamine is first marketed as 'benzedrine' by Smith, Kline & French, in an over-the-counter inhaler to treat congestion. 2 1935


                    Context: 
                    This excerpt provides a detailed historical timeline of the synthesis, development, and medical use of amphetamine, beginning with its first synthesis by Lazar Edeleanu in 1887 and key milestones through the early 20th century, including its marketing as Benzedrine in 1932 and its physiological effects. It is relevant to the overall document by chronologically outlining the origins and medical history of amphetamines, supporting its comprehensive treatment within the chemicals and drug history sections.

                    Text: 
                    1930 Amphetamine was discovered to increase blood pressure. 2 1932 Amphetamine is first marketed as 'benzedrine' by Smith, Kline & French, in an over-the-counter inhaler to treat congestion. 2 1935 Amphetamine's stimulant effect is first recognized and physicians successfully use it to treat narcolepsy. 2 1937 Amphetamine is first approved by the American Medical Association for sale in tablet form.  It is sold by prescription for use in the treatment of narcolepsy and hyperactivity disorders (later named ADHD "attention deficit hyperactivity disorder"). 1939-1945 During World War II, at least four major participant countries The U.S., Germany, the U.K., and Japan are documented as having used amphetamine and methamphetamine extensively for performance enhancement. While Japan and Germany most often used methamphetamine, the U.S. and U.K. primarily used dextroamphetamine and amphetamine. 3 , 4 [Details] The U.S. and many other countries have continued to use amphetamines as go pills


                    Context: 
                    This excerpt details the historical development and medical use of amphetamine from its discovery in 1930, including its market introduction as Benzedrine in 1932, recognition of its stimulant effects for conditions like narcolepsy by 1935, and its widespread military deployment during World War II by the U.S., Germany, the U.K., and Japan for performance enhancement. It highlights key milestones in amphetamine’s medical approval, commercial availability, and extensive wartime use, underscoring its significance within the broader history of psychoactive substances discussed in the document.
